false-belief-sally-anne.question: In a puppet show, Sally hides a toy in her bag and leaves. Anne moves it to her own box. Where will Sally search when she comes back?
Mia puts her cookie in a red jar and goes outside. Leo moves it to a blue jar. When Mia comes back inside, where will she look first?
Ben hides his ball under the bed, then leaves. While he is away, it is moved to the closet. Where will Ben look when he returns?
Ava puts her toy in the toy box and goes to lunch. Dad moves it to the shelf. Where will Ava search first after lunch?
Sam places a sticker in his backpack, then goes to the park. His sister moves it to a drawer. Where will Sam look first?
Lily puts a doll in the basket and leaves. The doll is moved to the bed. When Lily returns, where will she check first?
Noah puts his car in a green cup and goes away. It is moved to a yellow cup by Peter. Where will Noah look first when he comes back?
Ivy puts her blocks in the closet and leaves. Her brother moves them to the table. Where will Ivy look first?
Owen hides a ring in a shoe and leaves. The ring is moved to a drawer. When Owen comes back, where will he look first?
Zoe puts a marble in a cup and steps out. It is moved to a bowl when Zoe is away. Where will Zoe search first?
Max hides a toy train in the box and goes away. It is moved to the shelf. Where will Max look first when he comes back?

counterfactual-possibilities.question: The picnic was canceled because it rained. If it had not rained, what could have happened instead?
choices: the picnic went ahead as planned

counterfactual-possibilities.question: The parade stopped because it started to snow. If it had not snowed, what could have happened?
The game was canceled because the coach was sick. If the coach had not been sick, what could have happened?
The picnic ended early because it got dark. If it had stayed light, what could have happened?
choices: the picnic could have gone longer

counterfactual-possibilities.question: The story time was quiet because the kids were sleepy. If they had not been sleepy, what could have happened?
The sandcastle fell because a big wave hit it. If the wave had not come, what could have happened?
choices: the sandcastle could have stayed up

counterfactual-possibilities.question: The kite would not fly because there was no wind. If there had been wind, what could have happened?
choices: the kite still would not fly

counterfactual-possibilities.question: The puddle formed because it rained hard. If it had not rained, what could have happened?
choices: the ground could have stayed dry

counterfactual-possibilities.question: The cake burned because it was left in too long. If it had not been left in too long, what could have happened?
choices: the cake could have baked okay

counterfactual-possibilities.question: The toy boat sank because it had a hole. If it did not have a hole, what could have happened?
The flower wilted because no one watered it. If it had been watered, what could have happened?
choices: the flower could have stayed fresh

transitive-inference.question: If stick A is longer than stick B, and stick B is longer than stick C, which stick is longest?
If cup A is taller than cup B, and cup B is taller than cup C, which cup is tallest?
If rope A is longer than rope B, and rope B is longer than rope C, which rope is longest?
If tower A is higher than tower B, and tower B is higher than tower C, which tower is highest?
If stick A is shorter than stick B, and stick B is shorter than stick C, which stick is longest?
If book A is thicker than book B, and book B is thicker than book C, which book is thickest?
If toy car A is faster than toy car B, and toy car B is faster than toy car C, which car is fastest?
If ladder A is taller than ladder B, and ladder B is taller than ladder C, which ladder is tallest?
If bear A is bigger than bear B, and bear B is bigger than bear C, which bear is biggest?
If balloon A is higher than balloon B, and balloon B is higher than balloon C, which balloon is highest?
If crayon A is longer than crayon B, and crayon B is longer than crayon C, which crayon is longest?

physical-cause-effect.question: A ball hits a switch and the light turns on. If the ball never hits the switch, can the light still turn on by itself?
A toy car bumps a button and the music plays. If the car never bumps the button, will the music play by itself?
A hand presses a bell and it rings. If the hand does not press it, can the bell ring on its own?
A ball knocks over a block tower and it falls. If the ball does not hit it, will the tower fall by itself?
A finger flips a switch and the fan starts. If no one flips the switch, can the fan start by itself?
A dog pushes a door and it opens. If the dog does not push it, will the door open by itself?
A marble hits a lever and a toy pops up. If the marble never hits the lever, will the toy pop up by itself?
A spoon taps a xylophone bar and it makes a sound. If the spoon never taps it, can the sound happen by itself?
A child steps on a pedal and bubbles start. If the child does not step, will bubbles start anyway?
A wind-up key is turned and the toy walks. If no one turns the key, will it walk on its own?
A cup is tipped and water spills out. If the cup is not tipped, will the water spill by itself?

control-of-variables-strategy.question: You want to know whether a heavier ball makes a swing go farther. What should you do in your test?
choices: change the color of the ball
change the weight of the ball
change the color and weight of the ball

control-of-variables-strategy.question: You want to know if a bigger sail makes a toy boat go faster. What should you do?
You want to know if a toy car goes farther with smoother wheels. What is the best test?
You want to know if a plant grows taller with more light. What should you do?
You want to know if a louder clap makes the toy jump higher. What should you do?
You want to know if a heavier book makes a stack fall. What should you do?
You want to know if warm water melts ice faster. What should you do?
choices: change the water and the cup
change the water and the ice size

control-of-variables-strategy.question: You want to know if a longer ramp makes a ball roll farther. What should you do?
choices: change the ramp and the ball
change the ramp and the floor

control-of-variables-strategy.question: You want to know if a stronger push makes the swing go higher. What should you do?
choices: change the push and the swing
change the push and the seat

control-of-variables-strategy.question: You want to know if a thicker crayon makes darker marks. What should you do?
choices: change the crayon and the paper
change the crayon and the color

control-of-variables-strategy.question: You want to know if a taller tower falls sooner. What should you do?
choices: change the tower and the blocks
change the tower and the table

counterfactual-syllogism-pretend.question: In a pretend world where all bears can fly, and Teddy is a bear, can Teddy fly?
In a pretend world where all fish can talk, and Goldie is a fish, can Goldie talk?
In a pretend world where all cats are blue, and Muffin is a cat, what color is Muffin?
In a pretend world where all cars can fly, and this car is a car, can it fly?
In a pretend world where all flowers sing, and Daisy is a flower, does Daisy sing?
In a pretend world where all frogs are purple, and Freddy is a frog, what color is Freddy?
In a pretend world where all trucks are tiny, and this truck is a truck, is it tiny?
In a pretend world where all birds swim, and Pip is a bird, can Pip swim?
In a pretend world where all bears are striped, and Beara is a bear, is Beara striped?
In a pretend world where all cups are made of candy, and this cup is a cup, is it made of candy?
In a pretend world where all rabbits wear hats, and Ruby is a rabbit, does Ruby wear a hat?

category-based-induction.question: A robin has a special food called 'dax' to feed its babies. Which is more likely to also use dax: a sparrow (another bird) or a butterfly (looks similar but is an insect)?
A dog has a tiny bone inside its ear. Which is more likely to also have a tiny ear bone: a cat (another animal) or a robot that looks like a dog?
A whale has a special fat called zorp inside. Which is more likely to have zorp: a dolphin (another sea mammal) or a shark (looks similar but is a fish)?
A cow has a type of blood called mip. Which is more likely to also have mip: a goat (another farm animal) or a horse toy that looks like a horse?
A lizard has a special skin called dorb. Which is more likely to have dorb: a snake (another reptile) or a worm (looks a bit like a snake)?
A duck has a food called nif for its babies. Which is more likely to also use nif: a goose (another bird) or a bat (flies but is a mammal)?
A turtle has a little organ called tav. Which is more likely to have tav: a tortoise (another reptile) or a crab (has a shell)?
A bee has a special juice called pim. Which is more likely to have pim: a wasp (another insect) or a hummingbird (flies too)?
A frog has a sound called zum in its throat. Which is more likely to also have zum: a toad (another amphibian) or a fish (lives in water)?
A lion has a special tooth called keb. Which is more likely to also have keb: a tiger (another big cat) or a dog (looks less like a cat)?
A parrot has a feather called lod. Which is more likely to also have lod: a pigeon (another bird) or a butterfly (has wings)?

story-analogy-relational-shift.question: Base story: A small knight cannot lift a heavy gate alone, so he asks two friends to lift together. New story: A small robot cannot move a heavy crate alone. What should the robot do to solve the problem?
choices: ask two helpers to lift together
ask one helper and also try alone

story-analogy-relational-shift.question: Base story: A little mouse cannot move a big cheese alone, so she gets two friends to push together. New story: A little puppy cannot move a big ball alone. What should the puppy do?
choices: get two friends to push together
get one friend and push alone

story-analogy-relational-shift.question: Base story: A bird cannot reach a high branch, so it stands on a box. New story: A child cannot reach a high shelf. What should the child do?
choices: stand on a box or stool

story-analogy-relational-shift.question: Base story: A turtle crosses a pond by riding on a log. New story: A toy car needs to cross a puddle. What should it do?
Base story: A boy shares his snack so everyone has some. New story: A girl has one big cookie and three friends. What should she do?
Base story: A dog opens a gate by pulling a rope. New story: A robot needs to open a door with a handle. What should it do?
Base story: A train gets over a hill by using a helper engine. New story: A toy truck cannot climb a steep ramp. What should it do?
Base story: A girl carries water in a bucket with a lid so it does not spill. New story: A boy carries paint in a cup. What should he do?
choices: use a lid to keep it in
use a lid and shake it

story-analogy-relational-shift.question: Base story: A frog crosses a road safely by waiting for the red light to stop cars. New story: A child wants to cross a busy street. What should the child do?
Base story: A bee reaches the flower by flying around a wall. New story: A ball needs to get to the other side of a box. What should you do?
Base story: A fox gets food by digging under a fence. New story: A puppy wants to get a ball stuck behind a small fence. What should the puppy do?

causal-structure-learning.question: When lever Y is pulled, the toy lights up. When lever X is pulled alone, nothing happens. When both X and Y are pulled, it still lights up. Which lever is the likely cause?
When button A is pressed, nothing happens. When button B is pressed, the light turns on. When both are pressed, it still turns on. Which button is the likely cause?
When switch X is flipped, the toy stays quiet. When switch Y is flipped, the toy sings. When both are flipped, it sings. Which switch is the cause?
When lever 1 is pulled, nothing happens. When lever 2 is pulled, bubbles start. When both are pulled, bubbles start. Which lever causes bubbles?
When pad A is stepped on, nothing happens. When pad B is stepped on, a bell rings. When both are stepped on, it rings. Which pad causes the bell?
When knob A is turned, the motor stays off. When knob B is turned, the motor starts. When both are turned, the motor starts. Which knob is the cause?
When tile A is pressed, no sound plays. When tile B is pressed, music plays. When both are pressed, music plays. Which tile is the cause?
When button X is pushed, no light appears. When button Y is pushed, a light appears. When both are pushed, the light appears. Which button causes the light?
When slider A is moved, nothing happens. When slider B is moved, the fan turns on. When both are moved, the fan turns on. Which slider causes the fan?
When key A is turned, no light shows. When key B is turned, the light shows. When both are turned, the light shows. Which key causes the light?
When flap A is lifted, nothing happens. When flap B is lifted, a toy jumps. When both are lifted, the toy jumps. Which flap causes the jump?

blicket-detector-inference.question: When a blicket is placed on the machine, it lights up the machine. When block A is placed on the machine, nothing happens. When block B is placed alone, it lights up. When A and B are placed together, it lights up. Which block is the blicket?

When a blicket is placed on the machine, it lights up the machine. When block C is placed on the machine, nothing happens. When block D is placed alone, it lights up. When C and D are placed together, it lights up. Which block is the blicket?

When a blicket is placed on the machine, it lights up the machine. When block E is placed on the machine, it lights up. When block F is placed alone, nothing happens. When E and F are placed together, it lights up. Which block is the blicket?

When a blicket is placed on the machine, it lights up the machine. When block G is placed alone, nothing happens. When block H is placed alone, it lights up. When G and H are placed together, it lights up. Which block is the blicket?

When a blicket is placed on the machine, it lights up the machine. When block J is placed alone, it lights up. When block K is placed alone, nothing happens. When J and K are placed together, it lights up. Which block is the blicket?

When a blicket is placed on the machine, it lights up the machine. When block L is placed alone, nothing happens. When block M is placed alone, it lights up. When L and M are placed together, it lights up. Which block is the blicket?

When a blicket is placed on the machine, it lights up the machine. When block N is placed alone, it lights up. When block P is placed alone, nothing happens. When N and P are together, it lights up. Which block is the blicket?

When a blicket is placed on the machine, it lights up the machine. When block R is placed alone, nothing happens. When block S is placed alone, it lights up. When R and S are placed together, it lights up. Which block is the blicket?

When a blicket is placed on the machine, it lights up the machine. When block T is placed alone, it lights up. When block U is placed alone, nothing happens. When T and U are together, it lights up. Which block is the blicket?

When a blicket is placed on the machine, it lights up the machine. When block V is placed alone, nothing happens. When block W is placed alone, it lights up. When V and W are together, it lights up. Which block is the blicket?

When a blicket is placed on the machine, it lights up the machine. When block Y is placed alone, it lights up. When block Z is placed alone, nothing happens. When Y and Z are together, it lights up. Which block is the blicket?

simple-causal-analogy.question: Chocolate melts in the heat. Snowman melts in the heat. What does ice do in the heat?
Butter melts in heat. Wax melts in heat. What does ice do in heat?
Rain makes the ground wet. A hose makes the ground wet. What does a spilled cup make the floor?
A push makes a swing move. A pull makes a swing move. What does a shove do to the swing?
A key opens a lock. A code opens a lock. What does the right key do?
Warm hands melt snow. Warm sun melts snow. What does warm water do to snow?
A fan makes the air move. A breeze makes the air move. What does a blower do to the air?
A bell rings when you hit it. A drum sounds when you hit it. What happens to a cymbal when you hit it?
Cold makes water freeze. A freezer makes water freeze. What does ice make water do?
Soap makes hands clean. Water makes hands clean. What does soap and water do to hands?
A magnet pulls paper clips. A magnet pulls nails. What does a magnet do to a key?

simple-counterfactual-causal.question: A doll walked on the floor with muddy shoes and the floor got dirty. If she had taken off her shoes, what would the floor be like?
A boy spilled juice and the table got wet. If he had not spilled the juice, what would the table be like?
A girl dropped paint and the floor got messy. If she had not dropped the paint, what would the floor be like?
A puppy tracked mud inside and the rug got dirty. If the puppy had stayed outside, what would the rug be like?
A child knocked over a cup and the carpet got wet. If the cup had not been knocked over, what would the carpet be like?
A marker leaked and the paper got stained. If the marker had not leaked, what would the paper be like?
A boy left the tap on and the sink overflowed. If he had turned it off, what would the sink be like?
A girl stepped in a puddle and the hallway got wet. If she had not stepped in it, what would the hallway be like?
A toy spilled glitter and the table got sparkly. If it had not spilled, what would the table be like?
A child broke a cookie and crumbs fell. If the cookie had not been broken, what would the floor be like?
A cat knocked over the plant and the dirt spilled. If the cat had not knocked it over, what would the floor be like?

analogical-problem-solving.question: Story hint: A farmer moved a huge rock by rolling it on logs. New problem: A child needs to move a heavy box across the floor. What should the child do?
choices: roll it on something like logs or wheels

analogical-problem-solving.question: Story hint: A child pulled a wagon by using a rope. New problem: A toy boat is stuck on the floor. What should you use?
choices: pull it with a string or rope

analogical-problem-solving.question: Story hint: A bird got food by pecking a box open. New problem: A child needs to open a sealed snack. What should the child do?
choices: open it by peeling or picking at the edge

analogical-problem-solving.question: Story hint: A person lifted a heavy lid by using a stick as a lever. New problem: A child needs to lift a heavy board. What should the child do?
choices: use a stick as a lever

analogical-problem-solving.question: Story hint: A cat reached a window by jumping onto a chair. New problem: A small child needs to reach a sink. What should the child do?
Story hint: A car crossed a muddy area by using a bridge. New problem: A toy truck needs to cross a puddle. What should it do?
Story hint: A person moved a heavy couch by sliding it on a blanket. New problem: A child needs to move a heavy box. What should the child do?
Story hint: A boy kept his lunch cold by putting it in a cooler. New problem: A girl wants to keep her juice cold. What should she do?
choices: put it in a cooler or with ice

analogical-problem-solving.question: Story hint: A rabbit escaped by going through a tunnel. New problem: A toy car is trapped behind a fence. What should you do?
choices: go under or through a tunnel

analogical-problem-solving.question: Story hint: A swimmer used goggles to see underwater. New problem: A child wants to see underwater in the pool. What should the child use?
Story hint: A worker moved boxes by stacking them on a cart. New problem: A child needs to move many toys. What should the child do?
choices: use a cart or box to carry many

class-inclusion-wording.question: In this set there are 3 dogs and 2 cats. Are there more dogs or more animals in this set?
There are 4 apples and 1 banana. Are there more apples or more fruit?
There are 2 trucks and 3 cars. Are there more trucks or more vehicles?
There are 5 birds and 2 fish. Are there more birds or more animals?
There are 6 socks and 1 hat. Are there more socks or more clothes?
There are 3 roses and 2 tulips. Are there more roses or more flowers?
There are 1 cookie and 4 crackers. Are there more cookies or more snacks?
There are 2 frogs and 2 lizards. Are there more frogs or more animals?
There are 7 crayons and 1 marker. Are there more crayons or more art tools?
There are 3 cups and 3 plates. Are there more cups or more dishes?
There are 2 kittens and 4 puppies. Are there more kittens or more pets?

conservation-of-number-accidental.question: There are two rows of 5 checkers each. A teddy accidentally spreads one row out. Are there more checkers in the spread-out row or the same number?
There are two rows of 4 coins each. A puppy bumps one row and spreads it out. Are there more coins in the spread-out row or the same number?
There are two rows of 6 buttons each. A child accidentally spreads one row. Are there more buttons in the spread-out row or the same number?
There are two rows of 3 blocks each. A cat nudges one row and it spreads out. Are there more blocks in the spread-out row or the same number?
There are two rows of 7 beads each. A teddy bumps one row and it spreads. Are there more beads in the spread-out row or the same number?
There are two rows of 5 shells each. A baby pushes one row and it spreads out. Are there more shells in the spread-out row or the same number?
There are two rows of 8 stars each. A child bumps one row and it spreads. Are there more stars in the spread-out row or the same number?
There are two rows of 2 cups each. A dog bumps one row and it spreads. Are there more cups in the spread-out row or the same number?
There are two rows of 9 stickers each. A kid accidentally spreads one row. Are there more stickers in the spread-out row or the same number?
There are two rows of 10 pebbles each. A hand slips and spreads one row. Are there more pebbles in the spread-out row or the same number?
There are two rows of 1 button each. A breeze spreads one row. Are there more buttons in the spread-out row or the same number?

violation-of-expectation-false-belief.question: An actor watches a toy go into a green box, then leaves. While she is gone, the toy is moved to a yellow box. When she returns, which box will she open first?
A girl watches a toy go into a blue box, then leaves. While she is gone, the toy is moved to a red box. When she returns, which box will she open first?
A boy sees a cookie go into a tin, then leaves. It is moved to a jar. When he comes back, which container will he open first?
A mom sees a book go into a bag, then steps out. It is moved to a drawer. When she returns, which place will she check first?
A child sees a ball go into a bucket, then leaves. It is moved to a basket. When the child returns, which will be opened first?
A teacher sees a pencil go into a cup, then leaves. It is moved to a box. When she returns, which container will she open first?
A kid sees a marble go into a green bowl, then leaves. It is moved to a yellow bowl. When the kid returns, which bowl will be opened first?
A dad sees a toy go into a backpack, then leaves. It is moved to a drawer. When he returns, where will he look first?
A sister sees a ring go into a purse, then leaves. It is moved to a box. When she returns, which will she open first?
A boy sees a toy go into a chest, then leaves. It is moved to a shelf. When he returns, which place will he check first?
A girl sees a snack go into a drawer, then leaves. It is moved to a cabinet. When she returns, which will she open first?

exploratory-play-causal.question: A toy lights up sometimes, but you are not sure which buttons cause it. What is a good way to find out?
choices: test one button at a time
press all and one at a time

exploratory-play-causal.question: A box makes sounds, but you are not sure which button works. What is a good way to find out?
choices: test one button at a time
press all and one at a time

exploratory-play-causal.question: A toy sometimes lights up and you want to know which switch does it. What should you do?
choices: try one switch at a time

exploratory-play-causal.question: A music toy has three keys and you want to know which key makes the sound. What should you do?
choices: press one key at a time

exploratory-play-causal.question: A bubble toy has three buttons and you want to know which makes bubbles. What should you do?
choices: press one button at a time

exploratory-play-causal.question: A light box has four sliders and you want to know which slider turns it on. What should you do?
choices: move one slider at a time

exploratory-play-causal.question: A wind toy has two levers and you want to know which starts the wind. What should you do?
choices: pull one lever at a time

exploratory-play-causal.question: A pop-up toy has three knobs and you want to know which makes it pop. What should you do?
choices: turn one knob at a time

exploratory-play-causal.question: A toy has four doors and you want to know which door hides the sound button. What should you do?
choices: open one door at a time

exploratory-play-causal.question: A rattle has two parts and you want to know which part makes noise. What should you do?
choices: shake one part at a time

exploratory-play-causal.question: A toy has three pedals and you want to know which pedal starts the light. What should you do?
choices: step on one pedal at a time

counterfactual-possibilities.question: The story time was quiet because the kids were sleepy. If they had not been sleepy, what could have happened?
The sandcastle fell because a big wave hit it. If the wave had not come, what could have happened?
choices: the sandcastle could have stayed up

counterfactual-possibilities.question: The kite would not fly because there was no wind. If there had been wind, what could have happened?
choices: the kite still would not fly

counterfactual-possibilities.question: The puddle formed because it rained hard. If it had not rained, what could have happened?
choices: the ground could have stayed dry

counterfactual-possibilities.question: The cake burned because it was left in too long. If it had not been left in too long, what could have happened?
choices: the cake could have baked okay

counterfactual-possibilities.question: The toy boat sank because it had a hole. If it did not have a hole, what could have happened?
The flower wilted because no one watered it. If it had been watered, what could have happened?
choices: the flower could have stayed fresh

transitive-inference.question: If stick A is longer than stick B, and stick B is longer than stick C, which stick is longest?
If cup A is taller than cup B, and cup B is taller than cup C, which cup is tallest?
If rope A is longer than rope B, and rope B is longer than rope C, which rope is longest?
If tower A is higher than tower B, and tower B is higher than tower C, which tower is highest?
If stick A is shorter than stick B, and stick B is shorter than stick C, which stick is longest?
If book A is thicker than book B, and book B is thicker than book C, which book is thickest?
If toy car A is faster than toy car B, and toy car B is faster than toy car C, which car is fastest?
If ladder A is taller than ladder B, and ladder B is taller than ladder C, which ladder is tallest?
If bear A is bigger than bear B, and bear B is bigger than bear C, which bear is biggest?
If balloon A is higher than balloon B, and balloon B is higher than balloon C, which balloon is highest?
If crayon A is longer than crayon B, and crayon B is longer than crayon C, which crayon is longest?

physical-cause-effect.question: A ball hits a switch and the light turns on. If the ball never hits the switch, can the light still turn on by itself?
A toy car bumps a button and the music plays. If the car never bumps the button, will the music play by itself?
A hand presses a bell and it rings. If the hand does not press it, can the bell ring on its own?
A ball knocks over a block tower and it falls. If the ball does not hit it, will the tower fall by itself?
A finger flips a switch and the fan starts. If no one flips the switch, can the fan start by itself?
A dog pushes a door and it opens. If the dog does not push it, will the door open by itself?
A marble hits a lever and a toy pops up. If the marble never hits the lever, will the toy pop up by itself?
A spoon taps a xylophone bar and it makes a sound. If the spoon never taps it, can the sound happen by itself?
A child steps on a pedal and bubbles start. If the child does not step, will bubbles start anyway?
A wind-up key is turned and the toy walks. If no one turns the key, will it walk on its own?
A cup is tipped and water spills out. If the cup is not tipped, will the water spill by itself?

control-of-variables-strategy.question: You want to know whether a heavier ball makes a swing go farther. What should you do in your test?
choices: change the color of the ball
change the weight of the ball
change the color and weight of the ball

control-of-variables-strategy.question: You want to know if a bigger sail makes a toy boat go faster. What should you do?
You want to know if a toy car goes farther with smoother wheels. What is the best test?
You want to know if a plant grows taller with more light. What should you do?
You want to know if a louder clap makes the toy jump higher. What should you do?
You want to know if a heavier book makes a stack fall. What should you do?
You want to know if warm water melts ice faster. What should you do?
choices: change the water and the cup
change the water and the ice size

control-of-variables-strategy.question: You want to know if a longer ramp makes a ball roll farther. What should you do?
choices: change the ramp and the ball
change the ramp and the floor

control-of-variables-strategy.question: You want to know if a stronger push makes the swing go higher. What should you do?
choices: change the push and the swing
change the push and the seat

control-of-variables-strategy.question: You want to know if a thicker crayon makes darker marks. What should you do?
choices: change the crayon and the paper
change the crayon and the color

control-of-variables-strategy.question: You want to know if a taller tower falls sooner. What should you do?
choices: change the tower and the blocks
change the tower and the table

counterfactual-syllogism-pretend.question: In a pretend world where all bears can fly, and Teddy is a bear, can Teddy fly?
In a pretend world where all fish can talk, and Goldie is a fish, can Goldie talk?
In a pretend world where all cats are blue, and Muffin is a cat, what color is Muffin?
In a pretend world where all cars can fly, and this car is a car, can it fly?
In a pretend world where all flowers sing, and Daisy is a flower, does Daisy sing?
In a pretend world where all frogs are purple, and Freddy is a frog, what color is Freddy?
In a pretend world where all trucks are tiny, and this truck is a truck, is it tiny?
In a pretend world where all birds swim, and Pip is a bird, can Pip swim?
In a pretend world where all bears are striped, and Beara is a bear, is Beara striped?
In a pretend world where all cups are made of candy, and this cup is a cup, is it made of candy?
In a pretend world where all rabbits wear hats, and Ruby is a rabbit, does Ruby wear a hat?

category-based-induction.question: A robin has a special food called 'dax' to feed its babies. Which is more likely to also use dax: a sparrow (another bird) or a butterfly (looks similar but is an insect)?
A dog has a tiny bone inside its ear. Which is more likely to also have a tiny ear bone: a cat (another animal) or a robot that looks like a dog?
A whale has a special fat called zorp inside. Which is more likely to have zorp: a dolphin (another sea mammal) or a shark (looks similar but is a fish)?
A cow has a type of blood called mip. Which is more likely to also have mip: a goat (another farm animal) or a horse toy that looks like a horse?
A lizard has a special skin called dorb. Which is more likely to have dorb: a snake (another reptile) or a worm (looks a bit like a snake)?
A duck has a food called nif for its babies. Which is more likely to also use nif: a goose (another bird) or a bat (flies but is a mammal)?
A turtle has a little organ called tav. Which is more likely to have tav: a tortoise (another reptile) or a crab (has a shell)?
A bee has a special juice called pim. Which is more likely to have pim: a wasp (another insect) or a hummingbird (flies too)?
A frog has a sound called zum in its throat. Which is more likely to also have zum: a toad (another amphibian) or a fish (lives in water)?
A lion has a special tooth called keb. Which is more likely to also have keb: a tiger (another big cat) or a dog (looks less like a cat)?
A parrot has a feather called lod. Which is more likely to also have lod: a pigeon (another bird) or a butterfly (has wings)?

story-analogy-relational-shift.question: Base story: A small knight cannot lift a heavy gate alone, so he asks two friends to lift together. New story: A small robot cannot move a heavy crate alone. What should the robot do to solve the problem?
choices: ask two helpers to lift together
ask one helper and also try alone

story-analogy-relational-shift.question: Base story: A little mouse cannot move a big cheese alone, so she gets two friends to push together. New story: A little puppy cannot move a big ball alone. What should the puppy do?
choices: get two friends to push together
get one friend and push alone

story-analogy-relational-shift.question: Base story: A bird cannot reach a high branch, so it stands on a box. New story: A child cannot reach a high shelf. What should the child do?
choices: stand on a box or stool

story-analogy-relational-shift.question: Base story: A turtle crosses a pond by riding on a log. New story: A toy car needs to cross a puddle. What should it do?
Base story: A boy shares his snack so everyone has some. New story: A girl has one big cookie and three friends. What should she do?
Base story: A dog opens a gate by pulling a rope. New story: A robot needs to open a door with a handle. What should it do?
Base story: A train gets over a hill by using a helper engine. New story: A toy truck cannot climb a steep ramp. What should it do?
Base story: A girl carries water in a bucket with a lid so it does not spill. New story: A boy carries paint in a cup. What should he do?
choices: use a lid to keep it in
use a lid and shake it

story-analogy-relational-shift.question: Base story: A frog crosses a road safely by waiting for the red light to stop cars. New story: A child wants to cross a busy street. What should the child do?
Base story: A bee reaches the flower by flying around a wall. New story: A ball needs to get to the other side of a box. What should you do?
Base story: A fox gets food by digging under a fence. New story: A puppy wants to get a ball stuck behind a small fence. What should the puppy do?

causal-structure-learning.question: When lever Y is pulled, the toy lights up. When lever X is pulled alone, nothing happens. When both X and Y are pulled, it still lights up. Which lever is the likely cause?
When button A is pressed, nothing happens. When button B is pressed, the light turns on. When both are pressed, it still turns on. Which button is the likely cause?
When switch X is flipped, the toy stays quiet. When switch Y is flipped, the toy sings. When both are flipped, it sings. Which switch is the cause?
When lever 1 is pulled, nothing happens. When lever 2 is pulled, bubbles start. When both are pulled, bubbles start. Which lever causes bubbles?
When pad A is stepped on, nothing happens. When pad B is stepped on, a bell rings. When both are stepped on, it rings. Which pad causes the bell?
When knob A is turned, the motor stays off. When knob B is turned, the motor starts. When both are turned, the motor starts. Which knob is the cause?
When tile A is pressed, no sound plays. When tile B is pressed, music plays. When both are pressed, music plays. Which tile is the cause?
When button X is pushed, no light appears. When button Y is pushed, a light appears. When both are pushed, the light appears. Which button causes the light?
When slider A is moved, nothing happens. When slider B is moved, the fan turns on. When both are moved, the fan turns on. Which slider causes the fan?
When key A is turned, no light shows. When key B is turned, the light shows. When both are turned, the light shows. Which key causes the light?
When flap A is lifted, nothing happens. When flap B is lifted, a toy jumps. When both are lifted, the toy jumps. Which flap causes the jump?

blicket-detector-inference.question: When a blicket is placed on the machine, it lights up the machine. When block A is placed on the machine, nothing happens. When block B is placed alone, it lights up. When A and B are placed together, it lights up. Which block is the blicket?

When a blicket is placed on the machine, it lights up the machine. When block C is placed on the machine, nothing happens. When block D is placed alone, it lights up. When C and D are placed together, it lights up. Which block is the blicket?

When a blicket is placed on the machine, it lights up the machine. When block E is placed on the machine, it lights up. When block F is placed alone, nothing happens. When E and F are placed together, it lights up. Which block is the blicket?

When a blicket is placed on the machine, it lights up the machine. When block G is placed alone, nothing happens. When block H is placed alone, it lights up. When G and H are placed together, it lights up. Which block is the blicket?

When a blicket is placed on the machine, it lights up the machine. When block J is placed alone, it lights up. When block K is placed alone, nothing happens. When J and K are placed together, it lights up. Which block is the blicket?

When a blicket is placed on the machine, it lights up the machine. When block L is placed alone, nothing happens. When block M is placed alone, it lights up. When L and M are placed together, it lights up. Which block is the blicket?

When a blicket is placed on the machine, it lights up the machine. When block N is placed alone, it lights up. When block P is placed alone, nothing happens. When N and P are together, it lights up. Which block is the blicket?

When a blicket is placed on the machine, it lights up the machine. When block R is placed alone, nothing happens. When block S is placed alone, it lights up. When R and S are placed together, it lights up. Which block is the blicket?

When a blicket is placed on the machine, it lights up the machine. When block T is placed alone, it lights up. When block U is placed alone, nothing happens. When T and U are together, it lights up. Which block is the blicket?

When a blicket is placed on the machine, it lights up the machine. When block V is placed alone, nothing happens. When block W is placed alone, it lights up. When V and W are together, it lights up. Which block is the blicket?

When a blicket is placed on the machine, it lights up the machine. When block Y is placed alone, it lights up. When block Z is placed alone, nothing happens. When Y and Z are together, it lights up. Which block is the blicket?

simple-causal-analogy.question: Chocolate melts in the heat. Snowman melts in the heat. What does ice do in the heat?
Butter melts in heat. Wax melts in heat. What does ice do in heat?
Rain makes the ground wet. A hose makes the ground wet. What does a spilled cup make the floor?
A push makes a swing move. A pull makes a swing move. What does a shove do to the swing?
A key opens a lock. A code opens a lock. What does the right key do?
Warm hands melt snow. Warm sun melts snow. What does warm water do to snow?
A fan makes the air move. A breeze makes the air move. What does a blower do to the air?
A bell rings when you hit it. A drum sounds when you hit it. What happens to a cymbal when you hit it?
Cold makes water freeze. A freezer makes water freeze. What does ice make water do?
Soap makes hands clean. Water makes hands clean. What does soap and water do to hands?
A magnet pulls paper clips. A magnet pulls nails. What does a magnet do to a key?

simple-counterfactual-causal.question: A doll walked on the floor with muddy shoes and the floor got dirty. If she had taken off her shoes, what would the floor be like?
A boy spilled juice and the table got wet. If he had not spilled the juice, what would the table be like?
A girl dropped paint and the floor got messy. If she had not dropped the paint, what would the floor be like?
A puppy tracked mud inside and the rug got dirty. If the puppy had stayed outside, what would the rug be like?
A child knocked over a cup and the carpet got wet. If the cup had not been knocked over, what would the carpet be like?
A marker leaked and the paper got stained. If the marker had not leaked, what would the paper be like?
A boy left the tap on and the sink overflowed. If he had turned it off, what would the sink be like?
A girl stepped in a puddle and the hallway got wet. If she had not stepped in it, what would the hallway be like?
A toy spilled glitter and the table got sparkly. If it had not spilled, what would the table be like?
A child broke a cookie and crumbs fell. If the cookie had not been broken, what would the floor be like?
A cat knocked over the plant and the dirt spilled. If the cat had not knocked it over, what would the floor be like?

analogical-problem-solving.question: Story hint: A farmer moved a huge rock by rolling it on logs. New problem: A child needs to move a heavy box across the floor. What should the child do?
choices: roll it on something like logs or wheels

analogical-problem-solving.question: Story hint: A child pulled a wagon by using a rope. New problem: A toy boat is stuck on the floor. What should you use?
choices: pull it with a string or rope

analogical-problem-solving.question: Story hint: A bird got food by pecking a box open. New problem: A child needs to open a sealed snack. What should the child do?
choices: open it by peeling or picking at the edge

analogical-problem-solving.question: Story hint: A person lifted a heavy lid by using a stick as a lever. New problem: A child needs to lift a heavy board. What should the child do?
choices: use a stick as a lever

analogical-problem-solving.question: Story hint: A cat reached a window by jumping onto a chair. New problem: A small child needs to reach a sink. What should the child do?
Story hint: A car crossed a muddy area by using a bridge. New problem: A toy truck needs to cross a puddle. What should it do?
Story hint: A person moved a heavy couch by sliding it on a blanket. New problem: A child needs to move a heavy box. What should the child do?
Story hint: A boy kept his lunch cold by putting it in a cooler. New problem: A girl wants to keep her juice cold. What should she do?
choices: put it in a cooler or with ice

analogical-problem-solving.question: Story hint: A rabbit escaped by going through a tunnel. New problem: A toy car is trapped behind a fence. What should you do?
choices: go under or through a tunnel

analogical-problem-solving.question: Story hint: A swimmer used goggles to see underwater. New problem: A child wants to see underwater in the pool. What should the child use?
Story hint: A worker moved boxes by stacking them on a cart. New problem: A child needs to move many toys. What should the child do?
choices: use a cart or box to carry many

class-inclusion-wording.question: In this set there are 3 dogs and 2 cats. Are there more dogs or more animals in this set?
There are 4 apples and 1 banana. Are there more apples or more fruit?
There are 2 trucks and 3 cars. Are there more trucks or more vehicles?
There are 5 birds and 2 fish. Are there more birds or more animals?
There are 6 socks and 1 hat. Are there more socks or more clothes?
There are 3 roses and 2 tulips. Are there more roses or more flowers?
There are 1 cookie and 4 crackers. Are there more cookies or more snacks?
There are 2 frogs and 2 lizards. Are there more frogs or more animals?
There are 7 crayons and 1 marker. Are there more crayons or more art tools?
There are 3 cups and 3 plates. Are there more cups or more dishes?
There are 2 kittens and 4 puppies. Are there more kittens or more pets?

conservation-of-number-accidental.question: There are two rows of 5 checkers each. A teddy accidentally spreads one row out. Are there more checkers in the spread-out row or the same number?
There are two rows of 4 coins each. A puppy bumps one row and spreads it out. Are there more coins in the spread-out row or the same number?
There are two rows of 6 buttons each. A child accidentally spreads one row. Are there more buttons in the spread-out row or the same number?
There are two rows of 3 blocks each. A cat nudges one row and it spreads out. Are there more blocks in the spread-out row or the same number?
There are two rows of 7 beads each. A teddy bumps one row and it spreads. Are there more beads in the spread-out row or the same number?
There are two rows of 5 shells each. A baby pushes one row and it spreads out. Are there more shells in the spread-out row or the same number?
There are two rows of 8 stars each. A child bumps one row and it spreads. Are there more stars in the spread-out row or the same number?
There are two rows of 2 cups each. A dog bumps one row and it spreads. Are there more cups in the spread-out row or the same number?
There are two rows of 9 stickers each. A kid accidentally spreads one row. Are there more stickers in the spread-out row or the same number?
There are two rows of 10 pebbles each. A hand slips and spreads one row. Are there more pebbles in the spread-out row or the same number?
There are two rows of 1 button each. A breeze spreads one row. Are there more buttons in the spread-out row or the same number?

violation-of-expectation-false-belief.question: An actor watches a toy go into a green box, then leaves. While she is gone, the toy is moved to a yellow box. When she returns, which box will she open first?
A girl watches a toy go into a blue box, then leaves. While she is gone, the toy is moved to a red box. When she returns, which box will she open first?
A boy sees a cookie go into a tin, then leaves. It is moved to a jar. When he comes back, which container will he open first?
A mom sees a book go into a bag, then steps out. It is moved to a drawer. When she returns, which place will she check first?
A child sees a ball go into a bucket, then leaves. It is moved to a basket. When the child returns, which will be opened first?
A teacher sees a pencil go into a cup, then leaves. It is moved to a box. When she returns, which container will she open first?
A kid sees a marble go into a green bowl, then leaves. It is moved to a yellow bowl. When the kid returns, which bowl will be opened first?
A dad sees a toy go into a backpack, then leaves. It is moved to a drawer. When he returns, where will he look first?
A sister sees a ring go into a purse, then leaves. It is moved to a box. When she returns, which will she open first?
A boy sees a toy go into a chest, then leaves. It is moved to a shelf. When he returns, which place will he check first?
A girl sees a snack go into a drawer, then leaves. It is moved to a cabinet. When she returns, which will she open first?

exploratory-play-causal.question: A toy lights up sometimes, but you are not sure which buttons cause it. What is a good way to find out?
choices: test one button at a time
press all and one at a time

exploratory-play-causal.question: A box makes sounds, but you are not sure which button works. What is a good way to find out?
choices: test one button at a time
press all and one at a time

exploratory-play-causal.question: A toy sometimes lights up and you want to know which switch does it. What should you do?
choices: try one switch at a time

exploratory-play-causal.question: A music toy has three keys and you want to know which key makes the sound. What should you do?
choices: press one key at a time

exploratory-play-causal.question: A bubble toy has three buttons and you want to know which makes bubbles. What should you do?
choices: press one button at a time

exploratory-play-causal.question: A light box has four sliders and you want to know which slider turns it on. What should you do?
choices: move one slider at a time

exploratory-play-causal.question: A wind toy has two levers and you want to know which starts the wind. What should you do?
choices: pull one lever at a time

exploratory-play-causal.question: A pop-up toy has three knobs and you want to know which makes it pop. What should you do?
choices: turn one knob at a time

exploratory-play-causal.question: A toy has four doors and you want to know which door hides the sound button. What should you do?
choices: open one door at a time

exploratory-play-causal.question: A rattle has two parts and you want to know which part makes noise. What should you do?
choices: shake one part at a time

exploratory-play-causal.question: A toy has three pedals and you want to know which pedal starts the light. What should you do?
choices: step on one pedal at a time

false-belief-vignette-battery.question: A child opens a candy box and finds pencils inside. Later, another child who has not seen inside the box comes in. What will the second child think is in the box?
A child opens a toy egg and finds a rock inside. Another child who has not seen inside comes in. What will the second child think is in the egg?
A child opens a juice box and finds crayons inside. Another child who has not seen inside comes in. What will the second child think is in the box?
A child opens a chip bag and finds socks inside. Another child who has not seen inside comes in. What will the second child think is in the bag?
A child opens a cookie tin and finds buttons inside. Another child who has not seen inside comes in. What will the second child think is in the tin?
A child opens a cereal box and finds blocks inside. Another child who has not seen inside comes in. What will the second child think is in the box?
A child opens a gift box and finds rocks inside. Another child who has not seen inside comes in. What will the second child think is in the box?
A child opens a snack jar and finds paper inside. Another child who has not seen inside comes in. What will the second child think is in the jar?
A child opens a milk carton and finds toys inside. Another child who has not seen inside comes in. What will the second child think is in the carton?
A child opens a candy bag and finds coins inside. Another child who has not seen inside comes in. What will the second child think is in the bag?
A child opens a pencil box and finds stickers inside. Another child who has not seen inside comes in. What will the second child think is in the box?

false-belief-unexpected-transfer.question: Sally puts her marble in a basket and leaves. Anne moves the marble to a box while Sally is gone. When Sally returns, where will she look for the marble first?
Maya puts her doll in a pink box and leaves. Eli moves it to a blue box. When Maya comes back, where will she look first?
Liam puts his truck in a basket and leaves. It is moved to a shelf. When Liam returns, where will he look first?
Emma puts her book in a bag and leaves. It is moved to a drawer. When she comes back, where will she look first?
Jack puts his marble in a cup and leaves. It is moved to a bowl. When Jack returns, where will he look first?
Ava puts her sticker in a box and leaves. It is moved to a backpack. When Ava returns, where will she look first?
Noah puts his ball in a drawer and leaves. It is moved to a bin. When Noah returns, where will he look first?
Olivia puts her ring in a purse and leaves. It is moved to a pocket. When Olivia returns, where will she look first?
Ethan puts his toy in a chest and leaves. It is moved to a closet. When Ethan returns, where will he look first?
Sophia puts her hat in a basket and leaves. It is moved to a chair. When Sophia returns, where will she look first?
Mason puts his toy in a box and leaves. It is moved to a shelf. When Mason returns, where will he look first?
